PART 2: Short conversations (Questions 6-15)
Level: A2

Read the short conversation and answer the question.

Nutritionist: Good morning, Mrs. Salazar. I've reviewed your blood test results. Your cholesterol levels are a bit high.
Patient: Oh, I was afraid of that. What should I change?
Nutritionist: I'd recommend reducing saturated fats — that means less fried food, less red meat, and less butter. Try to eat more fish, vegetables, and whole grains.
Patient: What about eggs? I eat eggs every morning.
Nutritionist: One egg a day is fine, but try boiling or poaching them instead of frying.

(Original content — Study2One)
questionText: What does the nutritionist recommend Mrs. Salazar eat more of?
explanation: The nutritionist says: «Try to eat more fish, vegetables, and whole grains.» Option B matches this recommendation. Option A lists foods to reduce. Option C mentions eggs, which are allowed but not recommended to increase. Option D lists items not mentioned.

options.text: Fried food, red meat, and butter.
Fish, vegetables, and whole grains.
Eggs, cheese, and milk.
Bread, rice, and pasta.

questionText: According to the conversation, what is wrong with the patient's current diet?
explanation: The nutritionist says the patient's cholesterol levels are «a bit high» and recommends reducing saturated fats such as fried food, red meat, and butter. This implies the patient has been eating too many foods high in saturated fat. Option C captures this.

options.text: She is not eating enough calories.

Nurse: Mr. Duarte, you're being discharged today after your knee surgery. Here are your post-surgery instructions.
Patient: Great. What do I need to do at home?
Nurse: Keep the wound clean and dry for the first 48 hours. After that, you can take short showers, but don't soak the wound in water. No baths or swimming for two weeks.
Patient: And what about the pain?
Nurse: Take the prescribed painkillers every six hours. If the pain gets worse or you see redness around the wound, come back to the emergency room immediately.

(Original content — Study2One)
questionText: How long should the patient keep the wound dry?
explanation: The nurse says: «Keep the wound clean and dry for the first 48 hours.» Option A matches this instruction. Option B says 24 hours. Option C says one week. Option D says two weeks (which applies to baths and swimming, not keeping the wound dry).

options.text: For the first 48 hours.
For the first 24 hours.
For one week.
For two weeks.

questionText: When should the patient return to the emergency room?
explanation: The nurse says: «If the pain gets worse or you see redness around the wound, come back to the emergency room immediately.» Option D matches these warning signs. Option A says after 48 hours. Option B says when the medication runs out. Option C says for a routine check-up.

options.text: After 48 hours, for a routine check-up.
When the pain medication runs out.
Two weeks after surgery for a follow-up visit.
If the pain increases or there is redness around the wound.

Text 1: Hospital Green Energy Initiative

St. Margaret's Hospital has announced a major green energy initiative that aims to reduce the hospital's carbon footprint by 60% over the next five years. The plan includes installing 2,000 solar panels on the hospital roof, replacing all lighting with LED systems, and upgrading heating and cooling equipment to energy-efficient models.

«This is not just about saving money,» said hospital director Dr. Caroline Webb. «Hospitals are significant contributors to carbon emissions, and we have a responsibility to lead by example. A healthier environment means healthier patients.»

The hospital estimates the upgrades will cost $4.5 million but will save approximately $800,000 per year in energy costs. The solar panels alone are expected to generate 30% of the hospital's electricity needs. Several staff members have also volunteered to form a «Green Committee» to promote recycling, reduce single-use plastics, and encourage sustainable commuting among employees.

(Original content — Study2One)
questionText: What is the main goal of St. Margaret's Hospital's green energy initiative?
explanation: The text states the initiative «aims to reduce the hospital's carbon footprint by 60% over the next five years.» Option B captures this goal. Option A says to build a new hospital. Option C says to hire more staff. Option D says to increase patient capacity.

options.text: To build a completely new, modern hospital.
To reduce the hospital's carbon emissions by 60% in five years.
To hire environmental scientists to work at the hospital.
To increase the number of patients the hospital can treat.

questionText: How much does the hospital expect to save per year in energy costs?
explanation: The text states: «will save approximately $800,000 per year in energy costs.» Option C is correct. Option A says $4.5 million, which is the total cost of the upgrades. Option B says $2,000. Option D says $60,000.

options.text: $4.5 million.
Approximately $800,000.
Approximately $60,000.

Option B says they manage solar panels. Option C says they treat patients. Option D says they raise money.

options.text: To promote recycling, reduce plastics, and encourage sustainable commuting.
To manage the installation and maintenance of solar panels.
To treat patients who have environment-related illnesses.
To raise funds for the hospital's renovation project.

Text 2: New Diabetes Medication Approved

The National Health Agency has approved a new once-weekly injectable medication called Glytara for the treatment of type 2 diabetes in adults. In clinical trials involving over 8,000 patients across 12 countries, Glytara reduced average blood sugar levels (HbA1c) by 1.8 percentage points — significantly more than existing treatments, which typically achieve a reduction of 0.8 to 1.2 points.

In addition to its blood sugar benefits, patients taking Glytara experienced an average weight loss of 5.4 kilograms over 52 weeks, and a 26% reduction in the risk of major cardiovascular events such as heart attacks and strokes.

«This represents a major step forward for patients who struggle to control their blood sugar with current therapies,» said lead researcher Dr. Amara Okafor. The medication will be available by prescription starting next month, though the estimated cost of $350 per month has raised concerns about accessibility for lower-income patients.

(Original content — Study2One)
questionText: By how much did Glytara reduce average blood sugar levels in clinical trials?
explanation: The text states: «Glytara reduced average blood sugar levels (HbA1c) by 1.8 percentage points.» Option D is correct. Option A says 0.8 points, which is the lower end of existing treatments. Option B says 5.4, which is the weight loss figure. Option C says 26%, which is the cardiovascular risk reduction.

options.text: By 0.8 percentage points.
By 5.4 percentage points.
By 26 percentage points.
By 1.8 percentage points.

questionText: What concern has been raised about the new medication?
explanation: The text states: «the estimated cost of $350 per month has raised concerns about accessibility for lower-income patients.» Option B captures this concern. Option A says side effects. Option C says it only works for type 1 diabetes. Option D says it requires daily injections (it is once-weekly).

options.text: It has serious side effects that were discovered after the trials.
Its high cost may make it unaffordable for lower-income patients.

explanation: The text mentions two additional benefits: «average weight loss of 5.4 kilograms over 52 weeks» and «a 26% reduction in the risk of major cardiovascular events.» Option C mentions the cardiovascular benefit. Option A says improved sleep. Option B says stronger bones. Option D says better eyesight.

options.text: Improved sleep quality.

Text 3: Medical Drone Delivery Program

A pilot program in eastern Rwanda has demonstrated that drones can deliver blood products and essential medications to remote health clinics in under 30 minutes — a journey that would take over four hours by road. The program, operated by a company called Zipline, has completed more than 75,000 deliveries since its launch in 2016.

The drones fly autonomously at altitudes of approximately 100 meters and can carry up to 1.8 kilograms of medical supplies. When they arrive at a clinic, they drop the package by parachute without needing to land, then return to their base. Each drone makes an average of 12 deliveries per day.

«Before the drones, we sometimes had to turn patients away because we didn't have the right blood type,» said clinic manager Nurse Josephine Uwimana. «Now we can request blood and have it within 30 minutes. It has saved many lives, especially for mothers with complications during childbirth.»

The Rwandan government has expanded the program to cover 75% of the country, and similar programs are now being tested in Ghana, Nigeria, India, and the United States.

(Original content — Study2One)

Text 4: Patient Safety Reporting System

Mercy General Hospital has introduced a new anonymous digital reporting system that allows any staff member — from surgeons to cleaning personnel — to report safety concerns, near-miss incidents, and medication errors without fear of punishment. The system, called SafeVoice, can be accessed through a mobile app or the hospital intranet.

In the first six months, SafeVoice received 847 reports. Of these, 312 were medication-related incidents, 215 involved equipment malfunctions, 186 concerned communication failures between departments, and 134 reported unsafe physical conditions such as wet floors or broken handrails.

«The most important number is not the total reports — it's the 847 problems we now know about that we didn't know about before,» said patient safety officer Dr. Thomas Liu. «A blame-free culture encourages honesty, and honesty is the foundation of patient safety.»

Since implementing SafeVoice, Mercy General has seen a 34% reduction in preventable medication errors and a 22% decrease in patient falls.

(Original content — Study2One)
questionText: What is unique about the SafeVoice system?
explanation: The text states it «allows any staff member to report safety concerns, near-miss incidents, and medication errors without fear of punishment» and it is «anonymous.» Option C captures the key feature of anonymous, blame-free reporting. Option A says it tracks patient satisfaction. Option B says only doctors can use it. Option D says it replaces medical records.

options.text: It tracks patient satisfaction scores in real time.
Only senior doctors are allowed to submit reports.
Any staff member can anonymously report safety concerns without punishment.
It replaces the hospital's electronic medical records system.

questionText: What was the most common type of report submitted through SafeVoice?
explanation: The text breaks down the 847 reports: 312 medication-related, 215 equipment malfunctions, 186 communication failures, and 134 unsafe physical conditions. Medication-related incidents (312) are the highest number. Option A is correct.

options.text: Medication-related incidents.
Equipment malfunctions.
Communication failures between departments.
Unsafe physical conditions like wet floors.

questionText: What does Dr. Liu mean when he says «A blame-free culture encourages honesty»?
explanation: Dr. Liu argues that when staff are not punished for reporting errors, they are more likely to speak up. This honesty allows the hospital to identify and fix problems. Option B captures this reasoning. Option A says mistakes should be ignored. Option C says punishment improves performance. Option D says honesty is not important.

options.text: Staff should ignore mistakes to maintain a positive atmosphere.
When staff are not afraid of punishment, they are more willing to report problems.
Punishing staff for errors is the best way to improve safety.
Honesty is not as important as following hospital procedures.

caseText:
Text 5: Nursing Shortage Crisis

The International Council of Nurses has warned that the world could face a shortage of up to 13 million nurses by 2030, calling it a «global health emergency.» The shortage is driven by an aging nursing workforce, high rates of burnout, and insufficient enrollment in nursing education programs.

In many countries, nurses are leaving the profession in record numbers. A survey of 27,000 nurses across 10 countries found that 40% reported feeling «emotionally exhausted,» and one in four said they planned to leave nursing within the next two years. The COVID-19 pandemic worsened these trends, as nurses worked extreme hours under intense psychological pressure.

The consequences for patients are serious. Research shows that when nurse-to-patient ratios increase (meaning each nurse cares for more patients), rates of hospital infections, medication errors, and patient deaths also increase. A study published in The Lancet found that each additional patient per nurse was associated with a 7% increase in patient mortality.

Experts recommend higher wages, better working conditions, expanded scholarship programs for nursing students, and greater investment in mental health support for healthcare workers.

(Original content — Study2One)
questionText: How many nurses could the world be short of by 2030?
explanation: The text states: «the world could face a shortage of up to 13 million nurses by 2030.» Option D is correct. Option A says 27,000, which is the number of nurses surveyed. Option B says 40%, a burnout figure. Option C says 7 million.

options.text: 4 million.
7 million.
Up to 13 million.

questionText: According to the survey, what proportion of nurses plan to leave the profession within two years?
explanation: The text says: «one in four said they planned to leave nursing within the next two years.» One in four equals 25%. Option B is correct. Option A says 40%, which is the proportion who feel emotionally exhausted. Option C says 7%. Option D says more than half.

options.text: One in four (25%).
More than half.

questionText: According to the study published in The Lancet, what happens when a nurse is assigned one additional patient?
explanation: The text states: «each additional patient per nurse was associated with a 7% increase in patient mortality.» Option C is correct. Option A says costs decrease. Option B says nurse satisfaction improves. Option D says infection rates decrease.

options.text: Hospital operating costs decrease by 7%.
Nurse job satisfaction improves slightly.
Patient mortality increases by 7%.
Infection rates decrease because nurses work more efficiently.

caseText:
PART 4: Academic texts (Questions 31-55)
Level: B1-B2

Read the following text and answer the questions.

Text 1: Precision Medicine and Genomics

For most of medical history, treatments have followed a «one-size-fits-all» approach: the same medication at the same dose is prescribed to every patient with a given condition, regardless of individual differences. Precision medicine — sometimes called personalized medicine — challenges this model by using a patient's genetic profile, lifestyle, and environment to tailor treatments to the individual.

At the heart of precision medicine lies genomics, the study of an individual's complete set of DNA, including all genes. The Human Genome Project, completed in 2003 at a cost of $2.7 billion, produced the first full map of human DNA. Since then, the cost of sequencing a human genome has plummeted from millions of dollars to approximately $600, making genetic testing increasingly accessible.

One of the most successful applications of precision medicine is in oncology. By analyzing the genetic mutations present in a patient's tumor, oncologists can select therapies that specifically target those mutations. For example, patients with a particular mutation in the BRCA1 gene may respond well to a class of drugs called PARP inhibitors, while the same drugs would be ineffective for patients without that mutation.

Pharmacogenomics — the study of how genes affect a person's response to drugs — is another growing field. Research has shown that genetic variations can influence how quickly a patient metabolizes certain medications. A dose that is effective for one person may be toxic for another or entirely ineffective for a third, depending on their genetic makeup. Some hospitals now offer pharmacogenomic testing before prescribing medications such as blood thinners, antidepressants, and chemotherapy agents.

Despite its promise, precision medicine faces significant barriers. Genetic databases are disproportionately composed of data from people of European descent, meaning that treatments derived from this data may be less effective for other ethnic groups. Additionally, the cost of genetic testing and targeted therapies remains prohibitive for many patients in low- and middle-income countries. Ethical questions about genetic data privacy, the potential for genetic discrimination by employers or insurers, and the psychological impact of learning about one's genetic predispositions also remain unresolved.

(Original content — Study2One)

Option B captures this core idea. Option A says using the same treatment for everyone. Option C says treating only genetic diseases. Option D says replacing doctors with technology.

Option B says the cost increased. Option C says it remained the same. Option D says it is now free.

options.text: It has dropped dramatically from billions to about $600.

explanation: The text defines it as «the study of how genes affect a person's response to drugs.» Option B matches this definition. Option A describes genomics in general. Option C describes pharmacology. Option D describes genetics more broadly.

explanation: The text states: «Genetic databases are disproportionately composed of data from people of European descent, meaning that treatments derived from this data may be less effective for other ethnic groups.» Option A captures this lack of diversity. Option B says databases are too small. Option C says they are publicly accessible. Option D says they contain too many errors.

caseText:
Text 2: Mental Health Stigma Reduction

Mental health stigma — the negative attitudes, stereotypes, and discrimination directed toward people with mental health conditions — remains one of the greatest barriers to treatment worldwide. The World Health Organization estimates that in low- and middle-income countries, more than 75% of people with mental health disorders receive no treatment at all. Even in high-income nations, the treatment gap is approximately 35-50%.

Stigma operates at multiple levels. At the individual level, people may internalize negative beliefs about mental illness and feel shame or worthlessness, a phenomenon known as «self-stigma.» At the social level, family members, friends, and coworkers may distance themselves from or make hurtful comments about people with mental health conditions. At the structural level, discriminatory laws and policies may restrict the rights of people with mental health diagnoses — for example, limiting their ability to vote, hold certain jobs, or obtain insurance.

Research into stigma reduction has identified several effective strategies. Contact-based education, in which people with lived experience of mental illness share their stories directly with the public, has consistently shown the strongest effects in reducing prejudice. Media campaigns that portray mental health conditions accurately — avoiding sensationalism and stereotypes of violence or incompetence — also contribute to changing public attitudes.

In the healthcare setting, anti-stigma training for medical professionals is critical. Studies have found that healthcare workers themselves sometimes hold stigmatizing attitudes toward patients with mental health conditions, which can lead to dismissive treatment, misdiagnosis, and lower quality of care. Training programs that combine factual education with personal contact have been shown to improve clinicians' attitudes and behaviors.

Experts emphasize that stigma reduction must go beyond awareness campaigns. It requires systemic changes: integrating mental health into primary care, enacting anti-discrimination legislation, funding community-based mental health services, and ensuring that mental health is given the same priority as physical health in national health budgets.

(Original content — Study2One)
questionText: According to the text, what percentage of people with mental health disorders in low- and middle-income countries receive no treatment?
explanation: The text states: «more than 75% of people with mental health disorders receive no treatment at all.» Option C is correct. Option A says 35%, which relates to the treatment gap in high-income countries. Option B says 50%. Option D says 90%.

options.text: About 35%.
About 50%.
More than 75%.
More than 90%.

questionText: What is «self-stigma» as defined in the text?

Text 3: Maternal Mortality in Developing Countries

Every day, approximately 800 women die from preventable causes related to pregnancy and childbirth. The vast majority of these deaths — over 94% — occur in low- and middle-income countries. Sub-Saharan Africa alone accounts for roughly 70% of all maternal deaths worldwide, followed by Southern Asia.

The leading causes of maternal mortality include severe bleeding (hemorrhage), infections, high blood pressure disorders (pre-eclampsia and eclampsia), complications from delivery, and unsafe abortions. Most of these deaths could be prevented with access to skilled birth attendants, emergency obstetric care, and basic prenatal services. However, in many regions, healthcare facilities are scarce, understaffed, or located too far away for women to reach in time.

Socioeconomic factors play a critical role. Women in rural areas are three times more likely to die during childbirth than women in urban centers. Poverty, lack of education, early marriage, and gender inequality all contribute to higher maternal mortality rates. In some communities, cultural practices discourage women from seeking medical help during pregnancy, and decision-making about healthcare often lies with husbands or in-laws rather than with the women themselves.

International efforts have made some progress. Between 2000 and 2020, the global maternal mortality ratio declined by approximately 34%. Countries such as Rwanda, Cambodia, and Ethiopia have achieved dramatic reductions by investing in community health workers, training midwives, and building maternity waiting homes near hospitals. Yet progress remains uneven, and the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goal of reducing the global maternal mortality ratio to below 70 per 100,000 live births by 2030 remains far from being achieved.

Experts argue that lasting change requires addressing the root causes: investing in girls' education, empowering women to make their own healthcare decisions, strengthening rural health infrastructure, and ensuring that every woman has access to a skilled health professional during pregnancy and delivery.

(Original content — Study2One)

Text 4: Electronic Health Records Interoperability

Electronic health records (EHRs) have transformed healthcare documentation by replacing paper-based charts with digital systems that store patient information — including medical history, diagnoses, medications, lab results, and imaging reports — in a structured, searchable format. However, one of the most persistent challenges in healthcare informatics is interoperability: the ability of different EHR systems to exchange and use each other's data.

In most countries, hospitals and clinics use EHR systems from different vendors, each with its own data formats, coding standards, and software architecture. When a patient moves from one healthcare provider to another — for example, from a primary care clinic to a specialist or from one hospital to another — their records often cannot be transferred electronically. Instead, patients may need to carry printed summaries, repeat laboratory tests, or rely on their own memory to communicate their medical history.

This fragmentation has real consequences. Studies estimate that poor health information exchange contributes to 18% of medical errors in hospitals and costs the U.S. healthcare system alone approximately $30 billion annually in duplicated tests, delayed diagnoses, and administrative overhead. In emergency situations, the inability to quickly access a patient's allergy history, current medications, or previous diagnoses can be life-threatening.

Several international standards have been developed to address this problem. HL7 FHIR (Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources) is currently the most widely adopted framework, providing a standardized way for different systems to share patient data through application programming interfaces (APIs). Governments in the United States, the European Union, and Australia have introduced regulations requiring EHR vendors to support FHIR-based data exchange.

Nevertheless, achieving true interoperability requires more than technical standards. Some EHR vendors resist open data exchange because keeping patient data within their systems creates «vendor lock-in» — making it difficult and expensive for healthcare organizations to switch to a competitor's product. Patient consent and data governance are also complex: who owns the data, who can access it, and how is it protected when shared across institutional and national boundaries?

(Original content — Study2One)

Text 5: Pandemic Preparedness Frameworks

The COVID-19 pandemic exposed critical weaknesses in the world's ability to detect, respond to, and recover from large-scale infectious disease outbreaks. Despite decades of warnings from epidemiologists and the existence of international health regulations, most countries were inadequately prepared. Hospitals were overwhelmed, supply chains for personal protective equipment collapsed, and public health communication was often contradictory and confusing.

In response, the World Health Organization and several national governments have proposed comprehensive pandemic preparedness frameworks designed to prevent the failures of 2020 from recurring. These frameworks generally emphasize five pillars: surveillance and early warning systems, resilient health infrastructure, medical countermeasure development, coordinated governance, and equitable access to vaccines and treatments.

Surveillance is considered the first line of defense. Advanced genomic sequencing technologies can now identify novel pathogens within days of their emergence, compared to the weeks or months required in previous decades. Wastewater surveillance — monitoring sewage for traces of viruses — has emerged as a powerful tool for detecting community spread before clinical cases appear. However, these technologies are concentrated in high-income countries, leaving much of the world with limited early detection capacity.

Medical countermeasure platforms represent another key innovation. The mRNA vaccine technology used against COVID-19 demonstrated that vaccines could be designed within days of a virus's genetic sequence being published and manufactured at scale within months. Preparedness frameworks call for maintaining «warm» manufacturing bases — facilities that can rapidly pivot to producing vaccines and therapeutics when a new threat emerges — and for pre-negotiated agreements with pharmaceutical companies to ensure rapid and equitable distribution.

Perhaps the most contentious aspect of pandemic preparedness is governance. The proposed WHO Pandemic Treaty, currently under negotiation, seeks to establish binding commitments for pathogen sharing, technology transfer, and equitable access to medical countermeasures. Critics argue that it could infringe on national sovereignty, while supporters maintain that a coordinated global response is the only way to prevent a repeat of the inequitable vaccine distribution seen during COVID-19, when high-income countries secured the majority of vaccine doses while many low-income countries waited months or years for access.

(Original content — Study2One)
